Major News Round Up

While opening the new Charles Library and responding to the evolving COVID-19 pandemic, we were involved in a number of other important activities and initiatives. We have highlighted some of these major news items on the following pages.

In the same month that we opened Charles Library, we also launched a brand new library website after several years of development and user testing. It serves to enhance discovery of library resources, and to promote the use of services and amenities both online and within our walls.

As we celebrated the 100th anniversary of women’s right to vote this year, staff from the SCRC and Metadata and Digitization Services continued to work on “In Her Own Right: A Century of Women’s Activism, 1820-1920,” a project of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL). “In Her Own Right” is a multi-phase, multi-grant-funded project to digitize and make accessible primary sources documenting women working for women’s rights in the century leading up to women getting the vote in Philadelphia and beyond.

Library staff worked with the College of Public Health to help publish the first issue of their open access online journal, CommonHealth. A peer-reviewed journal, CommonHealth publishes papers of interest to public health scholars. The Libraries are hosting the journal via an open source platform, and all articles are immediately freely available to read, download, and share. This collaborative project showcases the groundbreaking work being conducted by our Temple students and faculty.

The Libraries launched TUScholarShare, the university’s digital archive for compiling, storing, and sharing the wide range of scholarly works created in the course of research and teaching at Temple. The repository makes Temple scholarship freely available online to a global audience, with the goal of advancing knowledge and learning.

In March, we installed a new exhibit in Charles Library: a preview of the forthcoming graphic novel Black Lives Always Mattered!: Hidden African American Philadelphians in the Twentieth Century. The graphic novel, which has been supported by The Pew Center for Arts & Heritage, is a project of the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection. The exhibit provides a glimpse of the beautiful artwork featured in the graphic novel scheduled for release in 2021 and is on display in Charles Library through November 2020, after which it will be on display at the Blockson Collection.

We celebrated the winners of the 16th annual Livingstone Undergraduate Research Awards. While we were unable to hold this year’s ceremony due to the pandemic, we created a special website (sites.temple.edu/livingstone) to showcase the incredible work of these talented undergraduates and recreated the experience of the live event by linking to the winner’s work, getting faculty statements about the winners, and sharing the winners’ reflections on their projects.

The Temple University Beasley School of Law Library hosted its first ever open house in September 2019. The event allowed students and faculty to mingle with librarians, vendors, and each other.

Librarians in the Learning and Research Services department launched a podcast and video series exploring behind the scenes work at the Libraries, available on our Human Sciences blog at sites.temple.edu/humansciences.

The Libraries continued to champion and support open access through the Open Access Publishing Fund, North Broad Press, and the Textbook Affordability Project. The first North Broad Press open textbook, Structural Analysis by Felix Udoeyo, was published this year.

At the end of the spring semester, we teamed up with the Philly Goat Project to livestream goats from their farm on the Libraries’ Instagram account. This goat project, which drew more than 80 viewers, was a creative, safe alternative to the therapy dogs we typically bring in to help students destress during exams.

The Ginsburg Health Sciences Library unveiled its newest resource for students, faculty, and researchers: the Presentation Practice Studio. The new studio is tailor-made for the Temple community at the Health Sciences Center to practice public speaking, prepare for academic or professional presentations, and experiment with prerecorded video to augment presentations.

In late May, the SCRC issued an open call for quarantine mail art as a way to document experiencing the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection launched the Dr. Ione D. Vargus Lecture Series, a programming series established by Dr. Ione Vargus. In January, the inaugural program featured Robert W. Bogle, president and CEO of The Philadelphia Tribune, and radio personality W. Cody Anderson in conversation.

Ambler Campus Library staff prepared materials to help Temple’s Landscape Architecture and Horticulture students and faculty to imagine, design, and build their 2020 Philadelphia Flower Show exhibit. Temple’s exhibit, “Course of Action: A Radical Tack for Suburban Tracts,” won top honors, including a PHS Gold Medal, the Alfred M. Campbell Memorial Trophy, and a PHS Gold Medal Plant Award.

In November, we hosted our first conference in Charles Library: OpenCon Philly, a free one-day series of panels and interactive workshops for idea exchange and learning around open access, open education, and open data. Members of the Libraries’ Scholarly Communications Strategic Steering Team worked in collaboration with librarians from across the region to put on this event.

As part of Love Data Week 2020, the Ginsburg Health Sciences Library unveiled its first art installation. The Tempestries exhibit was a series of crocheted tapestries from the Schuylkill Center for Environmental Education that used climate data and colored yarn to depict changes in average temperatures in Philadelphia from the 19th to the 21st centuries.

As part of a cross-departmental project involving Metadata and Digitization Services, the Loretta C. Duckworth Scholars Studio, the Special Collections Research Center, and Library Technology Development, we worked to make digitized books from the Paskow Science Fiction Collection available via HathiTrust.

Temple University Press books and authors won 13 awards, including a “Best Book of 2019” award by Foreign Affairs for Challenging Beijing’s Mandate of Heaven by Ming-sho Hos and a CHOICE Outstanding Academic Title award for Architectures of Revolt edited by Mark Shiel.

In December 2019, the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission (PHMC) awarded the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection a $10,000 Historical and Archival Records Care (HARC) grant. The grant will support conservation and preservation of the negatives in the John W. Mosley Photograph Collection, which provides a window into African American cultural, political, religious, and economic history in Philadelphia.

The Temple University Beasley School of Law Library received a Presidential Plaque of Appreciation in July 2020 from the American Association of Law Libraries.

New Acquisitions

The Libraries’ special collections include the Special Collections Research Center (SCRC) and the Charles L. Blockson Afro- American Collection. The SCRC houses the Libraries’ rare books, manuscripts, archives, university records, and important regional collections such as the Urban Archives and the Philadelphia Jewish Archives. The Blockson Collection holds a variety of rare and contemporary publications, photographs, archives, and manuscripts documenting African and African American life and history. Recent acquisitions help build these valuable collections for students, scholars, and members of the broader community engaged in research.

Select Special Collections Research Center (SCRC) Acquisitions

The SCRC added over 335 feet of material to its holdings during the year, including the following new collections:

Charles Austermuhl donated his collection of Walter de la Mare (1873-1956) first editions, association copies, dedication copies, and letters, gathered over 30 years of dedicated collecting. Poet and author de la Mare’s work has long been a collecting interest in Temple’s special collections, starting with first editions before World War I and a significant purchase of letters by Library Director Walter Hausdorfer in 1959.

Jonathan Jager, TYL ’68, served with the 7th PsyOp (Psychological Operations) Battalion in Da Nang, Vietnam in 1969-70. His collection of over 100 of original drawings and printed pieces document that work and includes captions he wrote for an exhibition with additional context about the images.

Among the small theatre company records we have received recently are those of Flashpoint Theatre Company (2004-2018), a Philadelphia company that focused on performing contemporary works with a social focus. They are perhaps best known for their annual productions of David Sedaris’s SantaLand Diaries. The records include administrative files, posters, ephemera, clippings and reviews, and production photographs.

At the end of spring semester and during summer session, Professor Mabel Rosenheck’s Intellectual Heritage classes created digital COVID scrapbooks reflecting their experiences during the pandemic.

An SCRC priority is to continue to gather archives created by Philadelphia’s many neighborhood associations. A recent addition is the records of Cedar Park Neighbors (1963-2013), including board minutes and bylaws; activity binders; grant, project, and subject files; newsletters; and website. CPN is just west of University City.

Select Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection Acquisitions

The Blockson Collection recently acquired the resolution by the Philadelphia City Council on the murder of Emmett Till and the coverage in Life Magazine. This document, signed by City Council President James H.J. Tate with ink stamp of Councilman Raymond Pace Alexander, states that the murder of Emmett Till caused “great shame and loss” and his trial was a “tragic miscarriage of justice.” The resolution congratulates Life Magazine for its October 10, 1955 issue, “In Memoriam Emmett Till.” Till was a 14-year-old Chicagoan visiting relatives in Mississippi, who was tortured, shot, and killed in August 1955, for allegedly whistling at a white woman. At the trial, his murderers were acquitted.

Reverend Nelson Carter (1808-1856) was an African Methodist Episcopal Church minister in Western Pennsylvania. This collection includes the family Bible, printed in 1847 by the American Bible Society, with a five-page handwritten insert of family births and deaths from 1808 through 1950. The family papers consist of photographs, handwritten and typed letters, a memorandum book, a ten-page family history with a two-page narrative of Jane Carter (1808-1900) under slavery, and two typed letters by her lawyer son William A. Butler of Washington, PA, one of which was to the Gazette Times stating that neither he nor his family had ever been “insulted because of color” in the town.

Our faculty and students, who often research historical representations of race in America, find cultural products such as advertisements excellent teaching tools. A new addition to the collection is: You Got to Have Soul! An advertisement for sheen conditioner, shampoo, afro combs, and other products by LaCrosby Beauty Supply Co., Inc. Jose LaCrosby (1927-2016) was a nationally renowned African American hairdresser in San Francisco who owned the company. The advertisement was published around 1970 at the height of the Black Power and Black Cultural Movements, when activists and intellectuals promoted the wearing of natural African hairstyles and the use of African influenced fashion.

Black Control of the Black Community: Vote Socialist Workers in 1970 is a document in keeping with the 1966 ten-point Black Panther Party platform, which demanded equal justice in all areas of life for African Americans and Black control of the Black community.

Another new acquisition is the Elaine Brown, Democrat City Council District #3 poster, which reads “Elect Elaine: Vote April 15th.” This poster was for Elaine Brown’s unsuccessful campaign to be on the Oakland City Council in 1973. Born in Philadelphia, Brown grew up on York Street in North Philadelphia. She graduated in 1961 from Philadelphia High School for Girls. After briefly attending Temple University, she moved to Los Angeles in 1965 and joined the Black Panther Party. A singer, Brown recorded two albums containing Black Panther themed songs and became a member of the Black Panther Party’s Central Committee. From 1973 through 1977, Elaine Brown was the chair of the Black Panther Party.

New Temple University Press Publications

Temple University Press is a leading publisher of books in the social sciences and the humanities, as well as books about Philadelphia and the Delaware Valley region. These selected titles represent a range of new Press offerings from the past fiscal year.

Shakespeare and Trump
Jeffrey R. Wilson
In this new book, Jeffrey Wilson asks the question: should we draw an analogy between Shakespeare’s tyrants—Richard III, Julius Caesar, Macbeth, and King Lear—and Donald Trump? From reading Trump’s first 100 days in office against Netflix’s House of Cards to exploring a summer 2017 Shakespeare in the Park production of Julius Caesar wherein an assassination of a Trump-ian leader caused corporations to withdraw sponsorship, Wilson uncovers a surprising—and bizarre—relationship between the provincial English playwright and the billionaire President of the United States, ostensibly a medieval king living in a modern world. The comparison reveals a politics that blends villainy and comedy en route to tragedy.

“Wilson’s take on Richard Gloucester, Frank Underwood, and Trump is as deft as it is insightful...it shows in compelling detail how Richard and Underwood win complicity from their on- and off-stage audiences, and then demonstrates how Trump and his various courtier-goons have used many of the same techniques.... Shakespeare and Trump is unmistakably personal; it is engaging, energetic, open and easy to read.”
—The Times Literary Supplement

Invisible People: Stories of Lives at the Margins
Alex Tizon, Edited by Sam Howe Verhovek, Foreword by Jose Antonio Vargas
Every human being has an epic story, according to the late Pulitzer Prize–winning writer Alex Tizon, who spent his career telling the epic stories of marginalized people. Edited by Tizon’s friend and former colleague Sam Howe Verhovek, Invisible People collects the best of Tizon’s rich, empathetic accounts—including the Atlantic magazine cover story about the woman who raised him and his siblings under conditions that amounted to indentured servitude, “My Family’s Slave.” Tizon’s pieces brim with enlightening details about people who existed outside the mainstream’s field of vision.

“Tizon’s talent was in seeking out those with stories to tell outside of the mainstream: those who don’t quite fit in, whether because of their race, religion, ethnicity, or lifestyle. Easy answers don’t exist in Invisible People; each piece leaves the audience a little bit unsettled, wanting more. The collection may focus on those who are invisible, but Tizon’s writing was anything but.”
— Foreword Reviews

The Great Migration and the Democratic Party: Black Voters and the Realignment of American Politics in the 20th Century
Keneshia N. Grant
Where Black people live has long been an important determinant of their ability to participate in political processes. In addition to its social and economic impacts, the Great Migration significantly changed the way Democratic Party elites interacted with Black communities in the northern cities of Detroit, New York, and Chicago. Many white Democratic politicians came to believe the growing pool of Black voters could help them reach their electoral goals and these Black migrants built coalitions with local parties as they became politically active. By focusing on the Great Migration’s significant political consequences for U.S. cities, Grant goes where few scholars have gone before and lays the groundwork for ways of thinking about the contemporary impact of Black migration on American politics.

Monument Lab: Creative Speculations for Philadelphia
Edited by Paul M. Farber and Ken Lum
What is an appropriate monument for the current city of Philadelphia? That was the question posed by the curators, artists, scholars, and students who comprise the Philadelphia-based public art and history studio Monument Lab. And in 2017, along with Mural Arts Philadelphia, they produced and organized a groundbreaking, city-wide exhibition of temporary, site-specific works that engaged directly with the community. The installations, by a cohort of diverse artists considering issues of identity, appeared in iconic public squares and neighborhood parks with research and learning labs and prototype monuments. Monument Lab is both a catalog of the exhibition and a critical reflection on the proceedings, including contributions from interlocutors and collaborators. A stunning achievement, the exhibition prompted civic dialogue about public art and history around what it means to be a Philadelphian, a conversation that remains especially relevant as we consider how to reflect on the meaning of social justice.

Good Reasons to Run: Women and Political Candidacy
Edited by Shauna L. Shames, Rachel I. Bernhard, Mirya R. Holman, and Dawn Langan Teele
After the 2016 U.S. Presidential election, a large cohort of women emerged to run for office. Their efforts changed the landscape of candidates and representation. However, women are still far less likely than men to seek elective office, and face biases and obstacles in campaigns. The editors and contributors to Good Reasons to Run, a mix of scholars and practitioners who are leaders in the field of women and politics, examine the reasons why women run—and do not run—for political office. They focus on the opportunities, policies, and structures that promote women’s candidacies and ask not just who wants to run, but how to activate and encourage such ambition among a larger, diverse population of potential female candidates.

Public Programs

Beyond the Page, the Libraries’ free public programming series, fosters conversations of social, scholarly, and educational value as we invite artists, writers, scholars, and experts in a variety of fields to address topics of importance to Temple and the surrounding community.

This past academic year, the opening of the new Charles Library inspired us to explore the history and future of the book. We examined how books have evolved, how libraries adapt to meet user needs, and what Charles Library makes possible for our staff and patrons.

In addition to this curated series, we offered a variety of panels, collaborations, workshops, performances, and lectures, such as our award-winning Beyond the Notes concerts and long-running Chat in the Stacks programs.

And while we had to postpone some of our spring programs amid the closing of the library buildings, we were able to swiftly move a number of events and workshops online in order to continue to offer academic and cultural programs to our users.

Highlights from this year’s programs include:

Faculty and graduate students delve into the history and future of the book
We invited several faculty members, graduate students, and alumni to Charles Library to discuss their own research on that most iconic of library resources: the book. We held two events—one in the fall and one in the spring—and heard about work being done at the Tyler School of Art and Architecture, the Lewis Katz School of Medicine, and in the English department via a series of fascinating lightning talks. SCRC staff also prepared pop-up exhibits featuring archival materials as part of these talks.

Building the 21st century library: reflections on a project completed
In 2016, we launched a multi-year program series in collaboration with the Tyler School of Art and Architecture to explore the process of building a 21st century library as we embarked on our own project here at Temple. And this past spring, we held the culminating event in this series in our new Charles Library event space with the architects, project managers, and other professionals involved in the design and construction of the new building reflecting on their work and the finished project.

Hands-on workshops exploring data art
As part of Love Data Week in February, the Ginsburg Health Sciences Library invited artists Mina Zarfsaz and Angela McQuillan to lead a hands-on workshop exploring the idea that we need to interpret data for it to have a cultural value. Participants learned how data can be represented using sound and created their own art. Later that week Mina Zarfsaz also gave a talk and led a demo with her students at Charles Library on Main Campus.

A virtual Juneteenth celebration: in memory of Bootsie Barnes
The Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection moved its annual Juneteenth program to Zoom this year for a virtual celebration of Black Music Month featuring the late Philadelphia jazz legend Robert “Bootsie” Barnes. The program featured Bootsie’s wife Sandra Turner Barnes, a performance by Bootsie’s grandson Reginald Lewis, and video of Bootsie’s performance at the Blockson Collection in 2014.

Pop-up concert in Charles
Charles Library has opened up new possibilities in programming for us, one of which is the ability to hold events in different areas throughout the building. In the fall, musicians from the Philadelphia Orchestra set up in the atrium and performed a free pop up chamber concert for visitors to the library.

Visit library.temple.edu/events to learn more about our programs and to browse upcoming events.

Library Stories

Read about how students, faculty, and community members are using and experiencing the Libraries, and hear from some of them in their own words.

A recent College of Engineering alum was able to get a quick answer to their eresources question from the librarian staffing Temple Libraries’ chat service, Andrew Diamond. The patron later wrote, “for me, as [a] recent alum, the library resources have been valuable as a resource for entrepreneurship and career development.” Their follow-up feedback was also glowing, “You can’t improve on perfection!”

Lisa Fitch, senior associate director of PhD programs in the Office of Research and Doctoral Programs at the Fox School of Business, reached out to Curator of the Blockson Collection, Diane Turner, after an event to say:
“A tremendous thank you for allowing FOX to use the Feinstone Lounge and the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection for the Fox School Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Networking Event yesterday. The space was beautiful and suitable for the celebration of Black History Month and Temple University’s history of supporting diversity, equity, and inclusion. The exhibitions were well received by the guests and I hope that our faculty, staff, and students who attended the event will encourage others to visit the Collection. Also, special thanks to Aslaku Berhanu and your staff for their assistance in providing materials and information to us during the event.”

A student needed help getting started on finding published research in the Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences. The librarian staffing Temple Libraries’ chat service, Sarah Jones, directed them to the libraries’ Communication Sciences and Disorders guide, which was exactly what they needed to jumpstart their research. The student wrote that the chat experience “couldn’t have been better. [The librarian] quickly and efficiently directed me to my intended resource with no delay. Much appreciated.”

While campus was closed, School of Social Work students working on literature reviews met with the social work librarian, Olivia Given Castello, via Zoom for advice on their research strategies for finding intervention studies on trauma treatment effectiveness, and tips on finding the full text of articles. One student wrote, “I only wish I had gone to her BEFORE I started my paper.”

To increase support of the Temple Health Sciences Center patrons, Health Sciences Libraries staff moved workshops online at the start of the pandemic. They also scheduled new workshops in increasing numbers. From March 17th to June 30th, they held 20 workshops with 320 registrants from across Temple, the region, and the world, including Temple alumni in California and students from Portugal.

Attendees enjoyed the opportunity to attend remotely and found the sessions engaging and well produced. Comments included:
“Great online transition—really I had no idea it was the first online presentation of this workshop since it ran so smoothly!”
“Zoom was an effective method to present this information. It went very smoothly and the polls were effective. I think that this is a good method for presentation in the future and would allow for larger groups to sit in on the information.”

Doctoral students in the Music Therapy Department are expected to know systematic review skills as part of their preparation for their dissertations. After Stephanie Roth, biomedical and research services librarian, assisted a student in understanding these skills, Dr. Wendy Magee sent this email to Stephanie: “As for the type of help you have provided, it is exactly health sciences help that the students need for these reviews. [...] So your specific skills for this class and level of work is really needed.”

The Law Library began a collaboration with Temple Law’s International Programs to provide resources to current and future students, as well as program alumni. The law librarians created a research guide geared towards international students’ needs and produced a series of videos on topics such as United States courts and government, taking the bar exam, and using legal databases.

The Innovation Space at Ginsburg Health Sciences Library continued to be a popular resource for teaching and learning. For example, Dr. Hillel Maresky (Radiology) taught residents cardiovascular anatomy with the Sharecare VR program in the Innovation Space, while Dr. John Duffy brought nursing students to the space to use the Empathy Training Software. And in November, the Innovation Space was a featured stop on tours Dr. John Daly, Lewis Katz School of Medicine (LKSOM) interim dean and dean emeritus, led for the Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Mitchell Morgan, and Executive Vice President and Provost, JoAnne Epps.

Masterman High School student Giuliana Alleva won 3rd place in the National History Day Senior Individual Documentary category. She did some of her research for “‘Don’t Buy Where You Can’t Work’: Leon Sullivan’s Fight Against Job Discrimination” in the Libraries’ Special Collections Research Center.

A third year School of Podiatric Medicine student experimented with the Podiatry Library’s 3D printer to make 3D models of arteries to help first year students learn about and visualize nerves and blood vessels.

Natalie Tagge, head of the Podiatry Library, always tells attendees at the “Best Practices in Poster Presentation” workshop that they can email her after the workshop with a poster for her to review. A student emailed Natalie asking if she would review her first-ever poster presentation that she would be submitting in two weeks, and Natalie provided feedback based on the content of the workshop.

Staff News

Staff Accomplishments

Recent Presentations, Publications, and Professional Service

Aslaku Berhanu, Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection librarian, completed work on an Institute for Museum and Library Services (IMLS) grant to conserve rare books in the Blockson Collection. She also gave an interview to the Urban Institute Center, a national nonprofit research organization, about her work on the grant.

Charles L. Blockson, curator emeritus of the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, was presented two awards in October 2019. The first was the 2019 Dr. Dorothy Porter Wesley Award for Excellence in contributing to the Information Profession. This was awarded by the Association for the Study of African American Life and History and presented to Mr. Blockson by Temple University President, Richard Englert. The second award, presented by radio personality W. Cody Anderson, was from the Masons.

Olivia Given Castello, head of the business, social sciences, and education Learning and Research Services unit, with collaborators Lauri Friedman from the Temple University School of Social Work and Joel Nichols from the Free Library of Philadelphia (FLP), received an ARL Venture Fund grant to sponsor trauma-informed services training for FLP and Temple Libraries staff. With fellow members of the Education & Behavioral Science Section’s (EBSS) Social Work committee, she co-presented an ACRL webinar Connecting Justice to Frameworks: Information Literacy in Social Work.

Michelle Cosby, director of the Law Library, was honored as one of the Fastcase 50, which recognizes leaders, visionaries, and innovators in the legal field. She also testified before the House Appropriations Subcommittee on the Legislative Branch in Washington, D.C. about funding for the United States Government Publishing Office and the Library of Congress and served as president of the American Association of Law Libraries, presiding over the Association’s first-ever virtual annual meeting.

Will Dean, research and data services librarian, presented a lightning talk about using his position as a REDCap administrator to effectively connect library services to our research community at the Empirical Librarians conference in February 2020.

Nicole DeSarno, instructional designer, and Olivia Given Castello, head of the business, social sciences, and education Learning and Research Services unit, co-presented a poster at the Center for the Advancement of Teaching’s 18th Annual Faculty Conference on Teaching Excellence entitled Reaching Them Where They Are: Put the Library Where Students are Learning with LMS Integration. It won 3rd place in the poster competition.

Kristina De Voe, English and communication librarian, presented “Intersections of Critical Information Literacy and Open Pedagogy: Zines and Wikipedia in the Classroom” at the 2020 Georgia International Conference on Information Literacy in Savannah, GA.

Courtney Eger, learning and engagement librarian, was selected to join the editorial board of the open access publication, Marketing Libraries Journal, and serves as a proofreader.

Andrea Goldstein, librarian, served on the universitywide Financial Literacy Committee.

Josué Hurtado, librarian and coordinator of public services in the SCRC, served as the founding chair of the Mid-Atlantic Regional Archives Conference’s Diversity and Inclusion Committee.

Aaron Javsicas, editor-in-chief of Temple University Press, spoke about book publishing as a career to English Studies master’s students in Rutgers Camden Professor Holly Blackford’s Proseminar.

Latanya Jenkins, government information librarian, was granted a summer 2020 stipend for the Teaching the Global African Diaspora one-day workshop for world history teachers from the University of Pittsburgh’s Alliance for Learning in World History. Latanya was also accepted into the summer/fall 2020 Library Freedom Institute.

Sarah Jones and Gretchen Sneff, science and engineering librarians, co-presented “Are Your Students Ready to Create Open Data?” at OpenCon Philly Philadelphia, PA in November 2019.

Mary Rose Muccie, executive director/scholarly communications officer for Temple University Press, served on the program committee and acted as a facilitator for the P2L4 (a community of university presses and research libraries with whom they have a reporting relationship) conference.

Vitalina Nova, education and community engagement librarian, co-authored an article on trauma-informed pedagogy including context and suggestions for information literacy instructors in Reference Services Review special issue, Academic Libraries and the 45th President.

Charlie Perkins, head of public services at the Beasley School of Law Library, provided a book review about Foundations of Information Ethics for the Law Library Journal and wrote a short article “Deepfakes, Cheap Fakes, and the Information Professional” for The CRIV Sheet: The Newsletter of the Committee on Relations with Information Vendors.

Jenny Pierce, head of the science, technology, engineering, and biomedical Learning and Research Services unit, was interviewed for and is quoted in an article, “How Medical Librarians Are Handling the Coronavirus Crisis,” for Library Journal.

Julie Randolph, reference librarian at the Beasley School of Law, is serving on the Board of Directors of Greater Philadelphia Law Library Association and chairs its Bylaws Committee and also served on AALL’s Legal Research Competencies Review Special Committee.

Katy Rawdon, SCRC coordinator of technical services, served on the Finance Committee of the Mid-Atlantic Regional Archives Conference (MARAC).

Stephanie Roth, biomedical and research services librarian, was an invited speaker for the NISO 2020 virtual conference entitled Researcher Behaviors and the Impact of Technology. Her presentation topic was “Tools to Support Systematic Review Research.”

Darryl Sanford, bibliographic assistant, served as a member of the Ambler Campus Sustainability Council.

Emily Schiller, bibliographic assistant II, participated in a panel titled “Stepping Forward: Temple’s Community Programs” at the Philadelphia Technology Learning Collaborative 2019 Annual Conference held at the Free Library of Philadelphia in November.

Caitlin Shanley, librarian and coordinator of Learning and Student Success, was a panelist at the NCOW Community Forum during Temple University’s National Coming Out Week in October 2019. Caitlin served as co-chair of the ACRL Women and Gender Studies Section Instruction Committee, and was elected Member-at-Large of the Section.

Margery Sly, SCRC director, served as the vice president of the Society of American Archivists’ Foundation and as a member of the SAA Dictionary of Archives Terminology Working Group.

Gretchen Sneff, science and engineering librarian, co-authored a data primer, Confocal Microscopy Data Curation Primer, with co-authors Susan Ivey, Amy Koshoffer, and Huajin Wang.

Natalie Tagge, head of the Podiatry Library, was invited to serve a three-year term on the Editorial Board of the Journal of the Medical Library Association.

Holly Tomren, head of Metadata and Digitization Services, co-authored “Creating Library Linked Data with Wikibase: Lessons Learned from Project Passage” along with Jean Godby, Karen Smith-Yoshimura, Bruce Washburn, Kalan Davis, Karen Detling, Christine Fernsebner Eslao, Steven Folsom, Xiaoli Li, Marc McGee, Karen Miller, Honor Moody, and Craig Thomas in OCLC Research.

Kimberly Tully, curator of rare books, served the Rare Books and Manuscripts Section of Association of College and Research Libraries (RBMS/ACRL) as a member of the Budget and Development Committee and as a member of the Scholarships Committee.

Diane Turner, curator of the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, participated in a book signing of Philadelphia Jazz Stories Illustrated: Volume One, which includes an essay and interviews by her, at the Barnes Foundation.

Sara Wilson, assistant director of library outreach and communications, wrote a column, “Goodbye, Paley… Hello, Charles!: Marketing a Library Move,” for Public Services Quarterly.

New Staff

Jim Boyce is the new Charles Library evening building supervisor. Jim has worked in various facilities management roles, most recently as a member of the groundskeeping department at Temple University. He is currently pursuing a bachelor of arts at the Tyler School of Art and Architecture in the Facilities Management program.

Lara Davidson is the new bibliographic assistant II in the Access Services department. She joins us from the Schoenberg Center for Electronic Text and Images at the University of Pennsylvania Libraries. Lara graduated from Maryland Institute College of Art with a BFA in photography with a concentration in sustainability and social practice.

Christopher Green is the new technical support specialist for Library Technology Services. He comes to us from the City of Philadelphia where he worked in the Office of Innovation & Technology and the Office of Property Assessment.

Geneva Heffernan is the new lead administrative specialist on the Library Outreach and Communications team. Geneva recently graduated from Klein College with a BA in Journalism and Economics. Previously, she interned for the Philadelphia Inquirer and worked with the Philadelphia Phillies as a marketing photographer.

Brian Hoffman is the new senior developer for the Library Technology Development team. Prior to joining Temple, Brian worked as a developer consultant on numerous library and archives projects, including OJS (Open Journals System), the IMLS funded “Saving Data Journalism” project, Harvard’s LibraryCloud system, and ArchivesSpace. Previously, he worked at NYU Libraries and Columbia University.

Rolando Portocarrero is the new evening bibliographic assistant II in the Access Services department. While attending Temple, Rolando worked as a circulation student worker in Paley Library.

Shaun Vigil is the new Temple University Press acquiring editor for the humanities. He brings a wealth of experience to the Press, including stints at Palgrave Macmillan, Cambridge University Press, and Columbia University Press.

Support the Libraries

Temple University Libraries’ core mission is to connect people and ideas, in order to enhance learning, research, clinical practice, and creativity. We work every day to provide important services, resources, programs, and spaces to students, faculty, staff, visiting scholars, and members of the broader community. Support from friends like you helps ensure the continued success of our library enterprise.

We hope you will consider supporting the Libraries today. There are a number of opportunities to make an impact, from gifts to support library resources, initiatives, and operations to collection-speci.c endowments and annual funds.

We also continue to seek support for the new Charles Library through gifts made to name specific spaces or directly to the Library Endowment, which provides dedicated, permanent funding for both the building and the services, collections, staff, and programs it houses. Find out more about Charles Library at library.temple.edu/explore-charles.

Additionally, you can secure your commitment to the Libraries through an array of planned giving vehicles. Learn more at giftplanning.temple.edu.

Visit giving.temple.edu/givetolibraries, email dwash@temple.edu, or call 215-204-9305 to make a gift today.

We are grateful for the continued support and guidance of our Library Board of Visitors:

Sandra Cadwalader, Chair, LAW ’74
Estelle Alexander, CLA ’69
Steve Charles, KLN ’80
John H. Livingstone, SBM ’49
Audrey Stein Merves
Susan Popkin
Russell C. Ring
Paul Steinke
Howard Trauger
Mark B. Vogel, CST ’76

*In memory of BOV member Leonard Mellman, CLA ’49.*

Our BOV members are all also wonderful supporters of the new Charles Library, and many have made gifts to the Library Endowment and to name spaces throughout the building. We thank them for their dedication and generosity.

attributes.label: Employment Opportunities
attributes.description:
Work with us


Thank you for your interest in working for Temple University Libraries and University Press (TULUP)!  We employ librarians, technology specialists, editors, archivists, facilities managers, administrative specialists, and more.
 
We serve the Temple community and beyond, including more than 37,000 students; over 2,000 full-time faculty; and researchers and visitors on Main, Center City, and Health Sciences Center campuses in Philadelphia and on our Ambler and Harrisburg campuses. We are committed to providing research and learning services, offering open access to our facilities and information resources, and fostering innovation and experimentation. 
 
Our collections total more than four million physical and digital titles, over 275,000 print and electronic journal subscriptions, and more than 700 research databases. We also collect, preserve, and provide access to a broad universe of special collections, including rare books, manuscripts, archives, and photographs in the Special Collections Research Center and the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American collection. As part of our library enterprise, the award-winning Temple University Press supports our mission to advance learning and scholarship.

TULUP employees are encouraged to take active part in the organization by serving on committees within the Libraries or at the university, and receive annual professional development funds. We offer a flexible work arrangement policy with options for remote work for many of our positions. Questions about employment can be directed to Richie Holland, Executive Director, Finance and Administration, University Libraries. 

Learn more about our locations (including our main campus Charles Library, opened in 2019), events, and library publications, and then view open positions listed on the right. 

For more general information about working at Temple—including compensation and benefits—check out Temple’s Office of Human Resources website.

Other Staff Positions at Temple (through Temple Human Resources)

Are you a Temple student looking for information on being a student worker? Learn more about library employment opportunities for Temple students.

attributes.label: Mission & Key Functions
attributes.description:
Mission

Connecting people and ideas to enhance learning, research, clinical practice, and creativity. 

Key Functions

Temple University Libraries & the University Press nourish and sustain the academic enterprise through:

  • Facilities, staff, collections, and services that support study, instruction, inquiry, and scholarship;
  • Instructional and service engagement with the learning environment to aid students in the exploration and discovery of new ideas and the development of informed critical thinking;
  • Provision of materials, tools, and expertise to amplify the productivity and extend the reach of students, scholars, researchers and clinicians;
  • Dissemination of ideas and culture through publishing, events, outreach, and collaborative programming with academic and community partners.
attributes.title: Mission & Key Functions

attributes.label: Operating Principles
attributes.description:
Stewardship

The libraries serve as trusted keepers of the intellectual and cultural record, collecting, describing, providing access to, and preserving a broad universe of materials, including physical and digital collections, rare and unique books, manuscripts, archives, ephemera and the products of scholarly enterprise at Temple. 

Personalized & Proactive Services 

The libraries provide learning and research services that are anticipative of and keyed to the unique needs, desires and characteristics of the constituents they serve, both through interpersonal interaction and through user-responsive technologies. 

Intellectual Rigor 

While the libraries serve students and faculty by simplifying access to resources that support learning, clinical practice, and research, they also recognize a mandate to value complexity and to facilitate tackling the challenging question rather than finding the easy answer. 

Openness

The libraries embrace as core to their mission: 

  • Barrier-free access for our community to a rich array of physical & digital resources to support learning and inquiry;
  • The unfettered flow of ideas, scholarship and knowledge to support learning, clinical practice, and research and to stimulate creativity and intellectual enterprise;
  • Engagement with faculty to leverage and create open educational resources for broad distribution and sharing;
  • Collaborative development of open source standards, tools, and software to meet the needs of the scholarly, library, and cultural heritage communities;
  • A climate of organizational transparency to engage and energize a professionally sophisticated staff.

Historically-Informed, Future-Directed Library & Publishing Practice 

Informed by their historical commitment to collect, organize, disseminate and preserve the intellectual and cultural record, the libraries and the university press act aggressively to transform their focus and approach for the digital age. 

Innovation & Experimentation 

Moving to the tempo of the digital age, the libraries and press are agile and quick to explore, test, and adopt where appropriate new and emerging services, tools and methods, in a spirit of trial and error, continuous learning, and ludic exploration. 

Partnership & Collaboration 

The libraries and press commit to work in partnership and collaboration with individuals, departments, colleges, the clinical enterprise, and community groups across the institutional, local, national, and global landscape to develop the best new services to support learning, research, and creativity. 

Civic Hospitality

The libraries and press recognize their role in providing a welcoming environment for community members in North Philadelphia and the greater Philadelphia region, including access to technology, lifelong learning & life skills development, and cultural programming. 

Diversity & Inclusion 

The libraries and press strive to engage, include and serve the full diversity of the Temple academic and local communities regardless of race, ethnicity, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, age, religion, socioeconomic status, veteran status, political affiliation, or (dis)ability. We commit to inclusive practices in our spaces, services, and resources, and to the recruitment and retention of a diverse workforce. 

Accessibility

The libraries and press commit to making their resources, systems, and services universally available to all who need to use them. 

Accountability

The libraries and press commit to evidence-based planning, decision-making, financial stewardship, and management and to the regular evaluation of organizational performance in addressing the education, research, and civic and cultural outreach needs and priorities of Temple University at large. 

(Revised and Re-affirmed, September, 2017)
attributes.title: Operating Principles

attributes.label: Strategic Actions
attributes.description:
Temple University Libraries & the University Press will foster learning, enhance intellectual life, amplify scholarly impact, and extend the reach of the imagination for their diverse local, national, and global communities through concerted action in these key areas: 

1. Designing and building a dramatically new library environment to serve as a catalyst for academic enterprise at Temple. 

At the heart of the Temple campus, this new central library will embody emerging modes of library mission while sustaining and transforming traditional library functions and commitments, with a quality and thoughtfulness of design that will be a model for other research universities nationally and internationally in the digital age. 

2. Enriching the environment for learning and student success. 

The libraries will be a rich ecosystem for learning, providing services, instruction, tools and materials in light of diverse and evolving student needs, interests and predilections, in dialog with faculty and administrators, with an emphasis on curricular integration of information literacy, personalization and personal contact. 

3. Developing programs, services, and resources to enhance intellectual productivity, scholarly infrastructure, new modes of research, and clinical care services. 

The libraries will support a diverse environment for the exploration of new modes of scholarship, engaging all fields of academic endeavor as a multi-disciplinary contact zone and intellectual workshop, connecting students, clinicians and scholars with collections, tools, librarians, and technical experts. 

4. Exploring new opportunities in publishing and scholarly communication. 

The libraries will engage in deep collaboration with Temple University Press, with Temple faculty, and with other organizations and academic institutions to identify and adopt new approaches for sharing scholarly products, for exploring sustainable economic models for university publishing, and for connecting local publishing initiatives with Temple’s faculty. 

5. Seeking partners in innovation and experimentation to add value to library programs and to identify new avenues for economic support. 

The libraries will connect with a broad set of partners and collaborators at Temple and beyond to amplify their capacity for innovation, invention, and the exploration of emerging opportunities, both in technological domains (gaming, data visualization, data management, digital scholarship, health informatics etc.) and in areas where new revenue opportunities may be involved (publishing, foundation support, corporate partnerships, donor support, joint training and certification programs, etc.). 

6. Serving as a center of intellectual and cultural life. 

The libraries will engage with schools and colleges, academic departments, interest groups, individuals, and community organizations to stimulate conversation, support the exchange of ideas, to provide a lively agenda of events, serving as a center of intellectual, cultural and civic life for Temple University and its neighboring urban community. 

7. Serving as a repository of record for archival, rare, and unique materials and providing broad access to those collections. 

Building on deep archives and special collections that reflect not only Temple’s institutional history, mission, and geographical centrality to the Philadelphia urban community, but also its commitment to intellectual engagement in the arts, book arts, and alternative movements, and recognizing the reputation of the Blockson Collection as an important resource for African American history and culture, the libraries will continue to expand their holdings, providing access to an ever growing set of their holdings in digital form. 

8. Building a world-class staff for leadership in the research library enterprise. 

Recognizing that leadership, innovation, creativity, and dynamism in any enterprise are the product of personal commitment and staff empowerment, the libraries will create a flexible and forward-looking work environment that embraces transparent management practices, clear communication channels, individual accountability, fiscal responsibility, efficiency, a culture of experiment and continuous learning, opportunities for growth, and work-life balance, with the goal of becoming a model organization for contemporary research libraries. 

9. Sharing the vision, making connections, broadening support. 

As Temple University Libraries realize the ambition to be leaders in defining 21st century academic librarianship, they must share their story and build on successes and lessons learned, identifying further opportunities for growth and innovation, and opening up new avenues for support and partnership via private, corporate and foundation philanthropy and through cooperative enterprise with other organizations and institutions nationally and globally. 

(Revised & Re-affirmed, September 2017)

attributes.label: SCRC homepage
attributes.description:
The Special Collections Research Center (SCRC) is the principal repository for and steward of the Libraries’ rare books, manuscripts, archives, and University records. We collect, preserve, and make accessible primary resources and rare or unique materials, to stimulate, enrich, and support research, teaching, learning, and administration at Temple University. SCRC makes these resources available to a broad constituency as part of the University's engagement with the larger community of scholars and independent researchers.

We ask that you familiarize yourself with the guidelines for requesting and using materials in the Reading Room and for requesting reference assistance if you cannot visit. The staff is pleased to assist you and answer any questions you might have.

Please be aware that many of our collections may be housed off-site, and require up to two business days to retrieve. Please contact us in advance so that materials may be relocated to the reading room for your visit.
attributes.title: SCRC homepage

attributes.label: Resources on African-American Heritage in Philadelphia
attributes.description:
Resources on African-American heritage in Philadelphia at the Blockson Afro-American Collection

Items included are manuscripts, books, pamphlets, prints, photographs, posters, audiotapes, newspaper clippings and other documents.

Core List of Books

Abrahams, Roger D. Deep down in the jungle ...: Negro narrative folklore from the streets of Philadelphia. Hatboro, Pa.: Folklore Associates, 1964.

Anderson, Elijah. Code of the street: decency, violence, and the moral life of the inner city. New York: W. W. Norton, 1999.

___________. The Cosmopolitan canopy: race and civility in everyday life. New York: W.W. Norton & Co., 2011.

Ballard, Allen B. One more day's journey: the story of a family and a people. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1984.

Biddle, Daniel R. and Murray Dubin. Tasting freedom. Philadelphia: Temple University press, 2010

Blockson, Charles L. Philadelphia's guide: African-American state historical markers. Philadelphia: Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, 1992.

_______________. African Americans in Pennsylvania: A history and guide. Baltimore:  Black Classic Press, 1994.
________________. African Americans in Pennsylvania: above ground and underground: an illustrated guide. Harrisburg: RB Books, 2001.

_________________. The President’s house revisited behind the scenes: the Samuel Fraunces Story. Eubank, Kentucky: Still Publications, 2013

Bowser, Charles W. Let the bunker burn. Philadelphia: Camino Books, 1989.

Brown, G. Gordon. Law administration and Negro-white relations in Philadelphia: A study in race relations. Philadelphia: Bureau of Municipal Research, 1947.

Countryman, Matthew. Up South: civil rights and Black power in Philadelphia. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2006.

Crumbley, D. Helen. Saved and sanctified: the rise of a storefront church in Great Migration Philadelphia. Gainesville: University Press of Florida, 2012.

Delmont, Matthew F. The Nicest Kids in town: American bandstand, rock ‘n’ roll, and the struggle for civil rights in 1950s Philadelphia. Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012.

Du Bois, W.E.B. The Philadelphia Negro: A social study. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1899.

Dunbar, Erica Armstrong. A fragile freedom: African American women and emancipation in the antebellum city. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2008.

Ershkowitz, Miriam and Joseph Zikmund, eds.  Black politics in Philadelphia. New York: Basic Books, 1973.
Fauset, Arthur Huff. Black Gods of the Metropolis: Negro religious cults of the urban north. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1944.

Franklin, V. P. (Vincent P). The education of Black Philadelphia: the social and educational history of a minority community, 1900-1950. Philadelphia, Pa.: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1979.

Hopper, Isaac T. Kidnappers in Philadelphia: Isaac Hopper's Tales of oppression, 1780-1843. New York: Garland, 1994.

Hunter, Marcus Anthony. Black citymakers: how the Philadelphia Negro changed urban America. New York: Oxford University Press, 2013.

Lane, Roger. Roots of violence in Black Philadelphia, 1860-1900. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1986.

___________. William Dorsey's Philadelphia and ours: on the past and future of the Black city in America. New York: Oxford University Press, 1991.

Levenstein, Lisa. A movement without marches: African American women and the politics of poverty in postwar Philadelphia. Chapel Hill: UNC Press, 2009.

McBride, David. Integrating the city of medicine: Blacks in Philadelphia health care, 1910-1965. Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 1989.

Nash, Gary B. Forging freedom: the formation of Philadelphia's Black community, 1720-1840. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1988.

Nelson, H. Viscount. Black leadership's response to the Great Depression in Philadelphia. Lewiston: Edwin Mellen Press, 2006.

Newman, Richard and James Mueller, eds. Antislavery and abolition in Philadelphia emancipation and the long struggle for racial justice in the City of Brotherly Love. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 2011.

Powell, J. H. Bring out your dead: the great plague of yellow fever in Philadelphia in 1793. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1949.

Rankin-Hill, Lesley M. A biohistory of 19th-century Afro-Americans: the burial remains of a Philadelphia cemetery. Westport: Bergin & Garvey, 1997.

Rose, Dan. Black American street life: South Philadelphia, 1969-1971. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1987.

Saunders, John A. 100 years after emancipation: history of the Philadelphia Negro, 1787 to 1963.Philadelphia: Free African Society, [1964?]

Toll, J. Barth, and Mariam I. Crawford, eds. Invisible Philadelphia: community through voluntary organizations. Philadelphia: Atwater Kent Museum, 1995.

Trotter, Joe William, Jr. and Eric Ledell Smith, eds. African Americans in Pennsylvania: shifting historical perspectives. University Park: Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission and the Pennsylvania State University Press, 1997.

White, Charles Frederick. Who’s who in Philadelphia: a collection of thirty biographical sketches of Philadelphia colored people … together with cuts and information of some of their leading institutions and organizations. Philadelphia: The A.M.E. book concern, 1912.

Willis, Arthur C. Cecil's City: A history of Blacks in Philadelphia, 1638-1979. New York: Carlton Press, 1990.

Willson, Joseph. The elite of our people: Joseph Willson's sketches of Black upper-class life in antebellum Philadelphia. University Park: Pennsylvania State University Press, 2000.

Winch, Julie. Philadelphia's Black elite: activism, accommodation, and the struggle for autonomy, 1787-1848. Philadelphia: Temple University Press, 1988.

_________. A gentleman of color: the life of James Forten. New York: Oxford University Press, 2002.

Wolfinger, James. Philadelphia Divided: race and politics in the city of brotherly love. Chapel Hill: UNC Press, 2007.

Magazine

Philly talk. Philadelphia: Talk Publications Inc., 1969-1976.

Newspaper

Philadelphia Tribune

Selected Archival Materials

A.M.E. Church Collection and other denominations:  annual reports, minutes, journals, quarterly reviews and The Christian Recorder publication.

Alpha Boule Collection (Sigma Pi Phi Fraternity):  rituals and ceremonies, governance documents, annual reports, photographs, correspondence, programs, announcements and other documents

Downingtown Industrial and Agricultural School: administrative and financial documents, publications, correspondence, scrapbooks, photographs, memorabilia and other ephemera.

Father Paul M. Washington Papers: correspondence, sermons, speeches, photographs, news clippings, and more.

John W. Mosley Photograph Collection: photograph prints and negatives of notable Black entertainers, social and political personalities, and general social life of Pennsylvania's African Americans.

Migration Series: audio tapes/oral histories- interviews with African-American individuals and/or families who have migrated to Philadelphia during or after the Great Migration.

Natalie Hinderas Collection: audiotapes, photographs, correspondence, writings, diaries, and other documents.
 

Ruth Wright Hayre Collection: brochures, books, letters, magazines, broadsides, scrapbooks, photographs, film strips and more.

Sara R. Isaac Collection of Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA) in Philadelphia: correspondence, UNIA dues cards, minutes, proceedings and a photograph of Ms. Isaac.

William Still Collection: photographs and correspondence.

attributes.label: Blockson homepage
attributes.description:
The Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection is one of the nation's leading research facilities for the study of the history and culture of people of African descent. This collection of over 500,000 items has materials on the global black experience in all formats: books, manuscripts, sheet music, pamphlets, journals, newspapers, broadsides, posters, photographs, and rare ephemera.

In addition, the collection houses selected artifacts, such as statues and busts. The collection must be used in-house.

Help preserve and improve accessibility to the rich, historical holdings found in the Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, as well as grow the collection. Donate to the collection endowment today. This fund will ensure that these materials remain accessible for current and future generations of students, scholars and the community.

attributes.label: Library Search Roadmap
attributes.description:
Based on feedback received from the university community, Temple University Libraries released an enhanced version of the Library Search on August 13th, 2018.

As part of this update, the following changes were introduced to the Library Search:
  • A new design approach to our main search, in which pre-filtered search results from different library resources and collections can be shown side-by-side
  • A new search interface for specific types of collections, including the Catalog and Articles Searches
  • Improved filtering options and relevancy for your search queries
  • Simpler buttons for accessing online resources, viewing item information, and requesting materials

Additional information about the current Library Search can be found in the Library Search FAQ's.

Work in Progress

Beyond the August release, the Libraries will be working on additional enhancements including new approaches to browsing and the recommendation of resources and services. As the library makes these changes, public release notes will be made available below.

Release Notes

January 8, 2019

  • Added navigation updates to user interface, including:
    • A new navigation menu bar for Everything, Books, Articles, Journals, and More search views
    • Persistence of basic queries across these search views
    • Changes to filters to provide visual cues and expanded search functionality
  • Added new request option for E-ZBorrow
  • Added summary notes for physical holdings to availability displays
  • Added electronic service notes for online materials to availability displays
  • Added separate field for “Genre” in catalog record displays
  • Updated “Cite” feature so that the citations are more accurate (now pulled from Worldcat-generated citations)
  • Updated availability display so that suppressed holdings do not appear
  • Updated search relevancy boosts for combined title/author searching
  • Fixed bugs with the “Request Item” form, including drop-downs for description and pick-up location
  • Fixed minor bugs for catalog record displays, including updates to title, author/creator, notes, and location fields

November 20, 2018

  • Added call number field to Advanced Catalog Search options
  • Added new record display fields, including SCRC collecting areas and separate mappings for production, distribution, and manufacture information
  • Modified search relevancy for further boost uniform titles, add more synonyms, and refine ISBN/ISSN searching
  • Updated date facet styling and labels
  • Fixed bug related to subject links and binding note displays
  • Fixed bug so that holdings/items suppressed from discovery in Alma no longer appear in Blacklight
  • Fixed minor display issues related to My Library Account, request forms, and the availability section
  • Updated Blacklight to version 6.16

October 3, 2018

  • Added sort options and date facet in Articles Search
  • Added location and call number information in text message export
  • Added RIS file download to “Send to” export options
  • Added Refworks integration for the article records
  • Added character limit for display of long record titles in search results
  • Excluded missing and lost items from availability displays
  • Fixed request options when items are only available on reserve at current pickup location
  • Fixed My Library Account and availability status displays in Internet Explorer
  • Fixed subject field displays and links for catalog records
  • Fixed creator/contributor displays for corporate names
  • Updated design of Advanced Search pages, including improved accessibility, and fixed bugs with advanced search parameters
  • (Also coming soon: Added call number field to Advanced Catalog Search options)

Feedback

We want to know what you think. If you see something that you like or that doesn’t work for you, please fill out our feedback form. We will consider your feedback into future improvements or enhancements.

Emily Toner
Technology Projects Librarian
emily.toner@temple.edu

David Lacy
Director of Library Technology and Knowledge Management Services
david.lacy@temple.edu

attributes.description:
Temple University Libraries
Annual Report
Fiscal Year 2019

About the Libraries

Temple University Libraries serve as trusted keepers of the intellectual and cultural record—including physical and digital collections, rare and unique books, archives, and the products of scholarly enterprise at Temple.

We are committed to providing research and learning services, to providing open access to our facilities and information resources, and to fostering innovation and experimentation.

The Libraries serve Temple’s students, researchers, teachers, and neighbors on Main, Center City, and Health Sciences Center campuses in Philadelphia and on our Ambler and Harrisburg campuses.

Contents

Message from the Dean
Library as Place: Exploring the Libraries of Temple University
Temple University Libraries by the Numbers
Major News Round Up
New Acquisitions
New Temple University Press Publications
New Digitization Projects
Public Programs

Support the Libraries

Dean of University Libraries
Joseph Lucia

Library Outreach and Communications Administrator

Editor

Designer
Rachel Cox

Visit our website at library.temple.edu
libraries@temple.edu
You can find us on Twitter at @TempleLibraries, Instagram at tulibraries, Facebook at Temple University Libraries.

Message from the Dean

Dear friends,

The 2019 fiscal year was a momentous one for Temple University Libraries. We celebrated the end of an era—the closing of Paley Library on Temple’s Main Campus in May. And we marked a new chapter for the university and our library enterprise, as we commenced the move into the spectacular new Charles Library. This building sets the stage for a new kind of academic library, and I am so proud that Temple is leading that charge.

As you read this report, Charles Library is open and thriving, and we look forward to sharing stories from our first year in this incredible new space in next year’s annual report.

Amid such big changes on Main Campus, we have continued to engage in our important work across all of Temple’s libraries. This year’s report shines a special light on our libraries as distinct and unique spaces serving a variety of communities in meaningful ways.

I am also proud to share with you other major news items, important acquisitions and publications, vital statistics, staff news, and stories from our patrons. This has been a remarkable year for Temple University Libraries, and I’m so excited for what the next year will bring. Thank you for being a part of our story and our future.

With warm regards,

Joe Lucia
Dean of University Libraries

Note: The 2019 fiscal year ran from July 1, 2018 to June 30, 2019.

Library as Place: Exploring the Libraries of Temple University

A library is many things: a collection of resources and materials, a center of culture, a house of knowledge and expertise, a physical place. In this year’s report, we honor the library as place and invite you to take a look at and learn about all of Temple University’s libraries.

While Paley Library served as our center of operations, that distinction has now passed on to Charles Library. Yet, the Libraries extend well beyond our Main Campus branch. On the following pages, we’ll highlight our other library locations in the Philadelphia area, which include the Health Sciences Libraries, the Ambler Campus Library, and the Beasley School of Law Library.

We also serve Temple University Harrisburg, and additional library locations include the Temple Rome Library and Japan Campus Library System.

A Fond Farewell to Paley Library

Since 1966, Samuel L. Paley Library served as Temple University’s Main Campus library. On May 9, 2019, we said goodbye to Paley Library as we welcomed students, alumni, faculty, staff, and members of the community into Paley one last time for a day of activities and celebration.More details about this event can be found in the summer 2019 issue of our newsletter, Speaking Volumes.

At the end of the day, we officially closed Paley Library to the public. The building will live on as “Samuel Paley Hall” as the new home for the College of Public Health and will continue to house the Center for Academic Advising and Professional Development for the College of Liberal Arts and the College of Science and Technology.

Charles Library officially opened to the public on August 25, 2019. It now serves as the intellectual and cultural heart of Temple’s Main Campus, and we cannot wait to share more with you as our first year in Charles unfolds.

Moving to Charles

We have been preparing for the move to Charles Library for several years, including this year’s project to measure and apply colored stickers to books to signal where they would go in the Automated Storage and Retrieval System or in the open stacks. The physical collections move process began in earnest once we closed Paley Library in May.

Over the course of the summer, we moved over 1.5 million books, many of which were loaded into the Automated Storage and Retrieval System, also known as the BookBot. Around 180,000 books were designated for open stacks shelving on the library’s fourth floor.

Staff from the Special Collections Research Center loaded approximately 12,000 records center cartons into the BookBot. SCRC materials were also moved into the rare book vault, compact shelving, and the Albert M. Greenfeld SCRC Reading Room shelves. It took us over 17,000 hours to load our general collections into the BookBot. Library staff spent thousands more hours

triaging books that were originally rejected by the BookBot for a variety of reasons. The move was a massive undertaking, and we are so pleased to have completed it!

The Health Sciences Libraries

The Health Sciences Libraries of Temple University serve the Schools of Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy, Podiatry, and the College of Public Health.

Ginsburg Health Sciences Library

The Ginsburg Health Sciences Library, named for Simmy and Harry Ginsburg, opened in June 2009 in the Medical Education and Research Building on the Health Sciences Center campus in North Philadelphia.

The library oﬀers a variety of study spaces, workshops, and a range of services from expert health sciences librarians. Ginsburg Library is home to the Innovation Space, which opened in 2017 and features a selection of 3D printers, scanners, and virtual and augmented reality systems.

Ginsburg Library offers two special use rooms for Innovation Space. The School of Podiatric Medicine

Krausz Library of Podiatric Medicine

The Krausz Library of Podiatric Medicine, named after Dr. Charles E. Krausz in honor of his many contributions to the profession and school, was founded in 1963. It’s located in the Temple University School of Podiatric Medicine in downtown Philadelphia.

Temple is home to one of only nine podiatry schools in the United States. In addition, staﬀ at the Podiatry Library have recently added library instruction into the curriculum and begun to oﬀer drop-in workshops.

The Krausz Library oﬀers bone models for students to check out for study, as well as a 3D printer that functions as an extension of Ginsburg Library’s Innovation Space. The School of Podiatric Medicine is also home to an extensive shoe museum.

Ambler Campus Library

The Ambler Campus Library supports students and faculty at Temple’s Ambler Campus, which was originally the site for the Pennsylvania School of Horticulture for Women, founded in 1910. In the 1950s, the school merged with Temple University’s Ambler Junior College to create Ambler Campus as we know it today.

The Ambler Campus Library opened in 1959. Today, it oﬀers teaching and learning resources for those engaged in the study of landscape architecture, horticulture, business, education, and criminal justice, and supports many general education and ﬁrst year studies classes.

Each year, Ambler Library staﬀ oﬀer research assistance and support for the Landscape Architecture and Horticulture program in the Department of Architecture and Environmental Design’s yearly Philadelphia Flower Show exhibit.

Law Library

Founded in 1913, the Temple University Beasley School of Law Library has a long history as a research library and a service-oriented facility to the Law School. Located in the Klein Law Building on Temple Main Campus, the library surrounds a six-story atrium and connects students to collections, classrooms, faculty oﬃces, and study areas.

Collection highlights include the Rawle Collection of English and American Law from the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. The Law Library is also home to the Rawle Reading Room, which is a replica of the mid-19th century library of William Rawle, a prominent Philadelphia lawyer.

In 1972, the law school building caught ﬁre, and students, staﬀ, and other members of the Temple community made a chain to pass library books out of the burning building. They managed to save a large number of rare and valuable volumes, but more than 150,000 books were destroyed. The library has since restored and enriched its collection.
